shared_text:
Jackson County Historic Courthouse
July 2 at 1:39 PM ¬∑

Archives will reopen July 6th!
Thank you all for your patience during this unusual time. Archives will be open Mon - Friday 10am - 3pm BY APPOINTMENT ONLY temporarily.
Please read the following statement from Charlotte Mealor:

COVID-19 guidelines for visitors to Jackson County Historic Archives:

Beginning July 6, we will be open by appointment only for the first several weeks. All guests and volunteers are required to wear a mask when interacting with each other. When working with documents and books, we cannot maintain the suggested distance of six feet. Hand sanitizer and gloves will be provided.

Because we are in a unique situation right now, please limit the number of people per visit to two (you and one other).

We look forward to serving the public by assisting with their family research, while at the same time be cautious and responsible during this stressful pandemic.

Contact: Charlotte Mealor, Archives Coordinator at 706-387-7684, or email
historic.committee@jacksoncountygov.com

Today, as many of you know, President Trump announced that he is making an emergency declaration to address the Coronavirus pandemic. The president declared emergencies under several different provisions of the law, which he said would not only free up nearly $50 billion in disaster money to fight the spread of the virus but also expand capacity at hospitals and reduce other health regulations that could slow action. You may ask; what does this mean for us? Here are the two main reasons for the declaration.

1. It frees up and redirects money and resources to help fight the pandemic. This means that Jackson County could be reimbursed for money spent directly related to helping fight the virus.

2.Allows the Department of Health and Human Services to modify or waive regulations for Medicare, Medicaid and other programs. Waiving those regulations would also bring about changes to the broader medical system. This includes making it easier for you to access a doctor online instead of having to actually go to the doctor.

Jackson County Emergency Management
March 13 at 9:52 PM ¬∑

Today, as many of you know, President Trump announced that he is making an emergency declaration to address the Coronavirus pandemic. The president declared emergencies under several different provisions of the law, which he said would not only free up nearly $50 billion in disaster money to fight the spread of the virus but also expand capacity at hospitals and reduce other health regulations that could slow action. You may ask; what does this mean for us? Here are the two main reasons for the declaration.

1. It frees up and redirects money and resources to help fight the pandemic. This means that Jackson County could be reimbursed for money spent directly related to helping fight the virus.

2.Allows the Department of Health and Human Services to modify or waive regulations for Medicare, Medicaid and other programs. Privacy is a big question we get when speaking within our community about the 2020 Census and all Census data in general. Your responses are kept private for 72 years! As of today you can not even see any information from the 1950 Census if for example you are doing genealogy or research into your family tree.

Census workers take a LIFETIME oath to never divulge anything they see or learn while working for the Census Bureau. NO other federal agency can access or see your information. As Jackson County continues to grow it is so VERY important that everyone living here is counted. Please be on the lookout for your invitation to participate around March 12th, 2020.
